## Outline
  1. Quantum ChromoDynamics in the continuum
  2. Why QCD is challenging
  3. The lattice QCD approach and Monte Carlo simulations
  4. The need for supercomputers
  5. Open questions and challenges
## QCD in the Continuum {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out" auto-animate-duration=1}
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{gauge}}+\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{matter}}$$
## QCD in the Continuum {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out" auto-animate-duration=1}
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[ F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]+\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big) \psi_f$$
## QCD in the Continuum {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out" auto-animate-duration=1}
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =\textcolor{#EB811B}{-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]} +\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f$$
:::: {.columns } ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge fields**:
$$\normalsize A_\mu(x) = \sum_{a=1}^8 A_\mu^a(x)\, T^a$$
- $\small \left[ T_a,T_b\right]= i f_{abc}T_c$ and $\small \left\{ T_a,T_b\right\}= \frac 1 2 \delta_{ab}$ - $\small A_\mu(x)$ encapsulates the 8 gluons - $\small A_\mu^a(x)\in \mathfrak{su}(3)$. ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - **Field strength tensor**:
$$ F_{\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu A_\nu - \partial_\nu A_\mu - i g \,[A_\mu, A_\nu] $$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge transformations**: $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
$$ \begin{array}{rcl} A_\mu & \longrightarrow & UA_\mu U^\dagger \\ F_{\mu\nu} & \longrightarrow & U\,F_{\mu\nu}\,U^\dagger \end{array} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"} - **Covariance**: - $\small F_{\mu\nu}$ transforms *homogeneously* - $\small \mathrm{Tr}[F_{\mu\nu}F^{\mu\nu}]$ is **gauge invariant** ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.0em; font-style:italic; color:gray; margin-top:-20px; margin-right:0px; text-align:right;"} **[Pure gauge]{style="color: #EB811B;"} â†’ already highly non-trivial:** confinement, glueballs, non-linear self-interactions... ::: ## QCD in the Continuum {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in" auto-animate-duration=0.0}
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} = -\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right] +\textcolor{#EB811B}{\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f}$$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Quark fields**: - $\small \psi_f(x)$ → flavor $\small f=1,\dots,N_f$ - Real world → $\small N_f = 6$ - Fundamental rep. of $\small \mathrm{SU}(3)_C$ - $\small \psi_f(x)$ → $\small (\textcolor{red}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{green}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{blue}{\psi_f(x)})$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" } - **Covariant derivative**: $$D_\mu = \partial_\mu - i g A_\mu$$ - Couples quarks to gluons - Ensures **local gauge invariance** ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge transformations**: $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
$$ \begin{array}{rcl} \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,\psi_f \\ \bar{\psi}_f & \longrightarrow & \bar{\psi}_f\,U^\dagger \\ D_\mu \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,D_\mu \psi_f \end{array} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"} - **Facts**: Quarks are never observed as free particles - Combined into **color singlets** â†’ hadrons - mesons ( $\small \pi^{\pm}, \pi^0\dots$) - baryons ( $\small p,n\dots$) ::: ::: :::: ## Chiral Limit in QCD {auto-animate=true} ::: {class="fragment"} **Chiral Transformations**:
$$\psi \;\longrightarrow\; e^{\,i \alpha \gamma_5/2}\, \psi;\quad \quad \bar{\psi} \;\longrightarrow\; \bar{\psi}\, e^{\,i \alpha \gamma_5/2}$$
in the $\small m_f \to 0$ is a symmetry of the Lagrangian ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Left / Right modes**: $$ \psi_L = P_L \psi, \quad \psi_R = P_R \psi $$ with $P_{L,R} = \frac{1\mp\gamma_5}{2}$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-24px;"} - $$ \bar{\psi}\, i\gamma^\mu D_\mu \psi = \bar{\psi}_\textcolor{red}{\small L} i\gamma^\mu D_\mu \psi_\textcolor{red}{\small L} + \bar{\psi}_\textcolor{blue}{\small R} i\gamma^\mu D_\mu \psi_\textcolor{blue}{\small R} $$
â†’ does **not mix** chirality
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-30px;" } - $$ \,\bar{\psi}m\psi = \bar{\psi}_\textcolor{red}{\small L} m \psi_\textcolor{blue}{\small R} + \bar{\psi}_\textcolor{blue}{\small R} m \psi_\textcolor{red}{\small L} $$
â†’ explicitly **couples** $\textcolor{red}{\small L}$ and $\textcolor{blue}{\small R}$
::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:20px;"} - **Chiral limit**: $\small m_u = m_d = 0$ ⇒ $\small \mathrm{SU}(2)_V \times \mathrm{SU}(2)_A \times \mathrm{U}(1)_V$ is a **global symmetry**: - QCD spectrum **does not show parity doubling**. ::: ## Chiral symmetry breaking in real QCD :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:30px;"} ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-20px;"} 1. **Spontaneous breaking** - $\small \langle \bar{\psi}\psi \rangle \neq 0$ (non-trivial QCD vacuum) - $\small \mathrm{SU}(2)_V \times \mathrm{SU}(2)_A \times \mathrm{U}(1)_V \;\;\longrightarrow\;\; \mathrm{SU}(2)_V \times \mathrm{U}(1)_V$ - 3 Nambuâ€“Goldstone bosons ⇒ the **pions** 2. **Explicit breaking** - light quark masses $\small m_{u,d} \neq 0$ - GMOR: $\small{ M_{\pi}^2 = (m_u + m_d)}\frac{\large \langle \bar{\psi}\psi \rangle}{\large f_{\pi}^2} \simeq 135 \mathrm{\, MeV}$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:20px;"} ::: :::: ## Interactions in QCD ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"} **Gauge invariance** not only dictates the kinetic terms, but also **fixes the interaction structure**: ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:10px; margin-left:120px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"} $\small \sim g \bar{\psi}\psi A$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-54px; margin-left:550px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"} $\small \sim g \partial A A A \quad \quad \quad \sim g^2 AAAA$ ::: :::{.r-hstack style="align-items:center; justify-content:center; margin-top:-10px;"} ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - **QED-like vertex** - quarkâ€“gluon interaction - analogous to electronâ€“photon in QED ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4"} - **New in QCD** - 3-gluon and 4-gluon self-interactions - consequence of non-abelian $\mathrm{SU}(3)_C$ - lead to confinement, asymptotic freedom, glueballs... ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:left;"} Quantum corrections lead to divergencies: Interactions are treated in the **renormalization framework** â†’ [**running**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} of the coupling $g(\mu)$. ::: :::{.r-hstack style="align-items:center; justify-content:center; margin-top:300px"} ::: ## Running of the Coupling :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Scale dependent** coupling: $\small g \,\longrightarrow\, g(\mu)$ ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - Governed by the **Î²-function**: $$\small \mu \frac{dg}{d\mu} = \beta(g), \quad \beta(g) = -\beta_0 \frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} + \mathcal{O}(g^5) $$ with $\small \;\beta_0 = 11 - \tfrac{2}{3} N_f$ ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - **Solution at 1-loop**: $$\small \alpha_s(\mu) \equiv \frac{g^2(\mu)}{4\pi} = \frac{1}{\beta_0 \ln(\mu^2 / \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}^2)} $$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-60px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Consequences**: - $\small \mu \to \infty \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \to 0 \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{asymptotic freedom}$ - $\small \mu \to \Lambda_{\text{QCD}} \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \to \infty \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{confinement}$ ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:right;"} QCD becomes strongly coupled in the IR â†’ [**non-perturbative tools**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} are required! ::: ## Confinement ::: {class="fragment"} - At low energies $\small \alpha_s(\mu) \gg 1$ ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **QCD potential**:
$$\small V(r) = -\,\frac{4}{3}\frac{\alpha_s}{r} + \sigma r \quad \quad \quad \;\sigma \approx 0.9\ \mathrm{GeV/fm} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-20px;"} - **Force**:
$$ \small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QCD}} \approx 0.9 \times 1.6\cdot10^{-10} \text{J}/10^{-15}\ \text{m} \approx 1.6\cdot10^{4}\ \text{N} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" style="position:absolute; left:267px; top:265px;"} ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-40px; margin-left:25px;"}
$\small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QED}} \approx 2.3 \cdot 10^{2} \ \mathrm{N}$
::: ::: {class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" style="position:absolute; left:-40px; top:308px;"} ::: ::: {.callout type='default' class="fragment" style="margin-top:130px; width:fit-content; margin-left:20px; margin-right:20px; margin-bottom:50px;"} ## Particle Data Group ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: :::: ## QCD at Low Energies ::: {class="fragment"} - For $\mu \sim \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}$: - $\alpha_s(\mu)$ is large - Perturbation theory breaks down ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - Physics is dominated by **non-perturbative phenomena**: - Confinement - Mass gap - Hadron spectrum & structure ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - Need **non-perturbative tools**: - **Lattice QCD** (first-principles numerical approach) - **Effective Field Theories** (low-energy approximations) ::: ## Lattice QCD :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="65%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Euclidean formulation**: Discretize space-time as a **4D grid** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - Introduces two natural **cutoffs**: - **UV** : lattice spacing $a$ - **IR** : finite volume $L^4$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Fields on the lattice**: - Quarks: $\;\psi(x) \;\;\to\;\; a^{-3/2}\psi(n)$ (sites) - Gauge fields: $\;A_\mu(x) \;\;\to\;\; U_\mu(n) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$ (links) ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - Gauge links act as **parallel transporters** ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Boundary conditions**: - Periodic (PBC) for gauge fields - Anti-periodic (APBC) for fermions ::: ::: ::: {.column width="35%"}
::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-30px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:center;"} **Take-home:** With cutoffs and discretization, QCD becomes a theory with **dimensionless variables** â†’ can be solved numerically using **Monte Carlo techniques**. ::: ## Testo su Due Colonne ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Colonna 1: Contenuto lungo che occupa metÃ  della slide. - Puoi aggiungere elenchi, paragrafi o immagini. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Colonna 2: Contenuto diverso o complementare. - Anche qui puoi aggiungere qualsiasi tipo di contenuto. ::: ::: ::: {.reveal-html}

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
